editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: THE NOBLE Stranger. As it was Acted at the Private House in Salisbury Court, by her Maiesties Servants.

q.l: Lenius irritant animos demissa per aures,
Quàm quae sunt oculis commissa fidelibus—

div.p: Imprinted at London by I. O. for Iames Becket, and are to be sold at his shop at the Inner Temple gate, in Fleet-streete. 1640.

list.item: Moronzo an ancient Lord, Father to Clara and Marania.

Two Students of the Law.
Plod.
Fledwit.

div.head: To the Worthy Knight Sir Edmund Williams, &c.
div.p:
THough Poems of this Nature have sustain'd such cruell fate, as if the (seeming) Catoes of the stage had judg'd the world, grown to a Plurifie in Wit, and no meanes left to Cure, save onely wounding; This Play, (I dare not say how worthy) was received generally well upon the Stage, which begets a hope, that having parted with my interest in it to the world, it will not fall under your Opinion, whom I presume to Elect as Iudge, not Patron: The latter being growne, by servile imitation to a word of forme descends beneath your worth: But by the first, your Candid censure has power to curbe that faction,
which swelling to be Criticall, extends (like bubbles) to such Ayrie thinnesse, that seeming all, they lose themselves to nothing. As for the name of Poet, it is a stile I never aimed at, (though afarre off I have admired their sacred Raptures) and therefore will not be injurious to your Expectation, to bribe your Acceptance with promising Workes of a higher strain hereafter, this being only the Issue of some vacant houres, which if you vouchsafe at like times to smile on, there ends the ambition of him, who at becomming distance, desires to be knowne

div.head: To his Friend the Author on his Comedy, called the Noble Stranger.
div.l: FRiend, from me thou canst not expect a praise,
My Muse can give no Cypres nor no Baies:
She cannot though she would be vile, expresse
One syllable to make thy merits lesse:
Nor can she, had she rob'd the fluent store
Of Donns wise Genius, make thy merits more:
No, 'tis thy owne smooth numbers must preferre
Thy Stranger to the Globe-like Theatre.
But yet perhaps some squint-ey'd set will look
Worse then Magicians when they spell the book
Of exorcisme, yet doe not feare the danger
Of Critick Readers, since thy Noble Stranger,
With pleasing strains has smooth'd the rugged Fate
Of oft cram'd Theatres, and prov'd fortunate:
Smile at their Frownes, for I dare boldly say,
Who ere dislikes it cannot mend thy Play.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: BLest Fate protect me! what a lustre's here?
How many Starres deck this our little spheare?
And all predominate, have the influence
To blast, or cherish, punish, or dispence:
Your aspects yet are cleare, then joyn in one,
And prove a happy constellation.
Our Author does beleeve there will not want
Some to subscribe the Factious Covenant
Of your prescitian wits, if such there are,
Proclaime 'hem Rebells, and bid open warre.
'Las Poesie's become so shallow now,
All knowes to judge, what like, what disallow.
The briske Shops fore-man undertakes with's Ell
To sound the depth of Aganippas Well:
Weigh out each syllable, measure each line,
And then with as much confidence define
Whether false or currant, as those who know
Distinction 'twixt Phaebean straines and low.
Our Country audience too will crye downe playes;
And why, there is not foole enough he sayes.
Gentlemen, y' are grown queasie too of late,
'Tis meere variety does satiate.
Faith use our Author well, breath gentle ayre:
Force not his blooming hopes to a despaire.
'Tis the first accent of his tender Muse,
He hopes 'twill please you; if not, doe not use
A severe Censure, for by me he prayes
Crowne not with Cypres, though you give no Bayes.

div.head: ACTVS PRIMVS.
div.stage: Senate flourish. Enter King of Naples, on his head a wreath of Bayes, as from Conquest, Honorio, Fabianus, Philomusus, Callidus, Souldiers and attendants at one side of the Stage: Moronzo, Princesse, Clara, Marania, &c. at the other.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: HOw fares our Princely daughter? how hast thou
Brook'd the long absence of our tedious warre,
Wherewith we have in blood drown'd those Rebells
That sought the downfall of our Peace and State,
And now return'd, crown'd with victorious Laurell?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Most royall Father, I have with sighes and teares,
Numbred the jarring minutes since your sad
Departure, and had ere this been wrapt i'the cold
Embraces of the grave, had not the great Antidote
Of a Fathers blessing, given me at
Your departure, beene my Protector from
Death and Fortunes frowne, a renewing of
Which, thus on my knees I crave. Kneeles.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rise, thou hast it:
And may all those joyes that tender mothers
Wish their young infants, playing in their armes,
Be multiply'd upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The King's transported.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Has he not cause, possest of such a treasure;
That did Kings know it, they would pay their Crownes
As tribute to her vertue.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You speak not as a stranger of the Court;
But like one had spent his time in study
Of the Courtly Rhetoricke.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: No more: see the King addresses him
This way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now the rugged brow of Warre is
(By that power which protects Kings sacred persons,
And their rights) made faire and smooth agen,
Looke with a gracious eye on these whose true
Worth deserves the stile of Noble: these
Are they whose armes and swords have beene
Supporters of our lives and State, so as
In honour we must needs shew such grace
Their valour has deserv'd.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: All that a maid may doe, ty'd by duty
To a Fathers will, freely I performe: They kisse her hand.
As for the Common Souldiers, let your
Bounty flow in Gold as largies for their
Well spent labours.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Excellent Lady.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Moronzo 'tis your charge to give each one A free reward.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I shall my Liege.
Souldiers meet me at the publicke Treasury.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: We shall; Heavens crown our King with peace. Ex. Sold.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But for these, my Kingdome's all too little,
Especially this Gentleman, being To Honorie.
A stranger: and as he sayes a
Sycilian borne, but for some causes
Recorded within himselfe, which Ile not urge,
Came to inhabite in our confines, and
When our Quarrell, almost desperate with
The enemy had like to be overthrowne
For want of present aid, this most noble
Deserver of the stile of valour, not
Onely in person, but with a flowing
Measure of Coyne and Servants came unto
Our aide, by which we wonne the day.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The King does largely praise him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: And nobly he deserves it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: We're but foyles to set his lustre off.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Envy no honour the King pleases to conferre
Upon him: for in his noble breast both
Our deservings meet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Great King, how ere you please to shoure thus
Your favours on my poore deserts, being
A stranger, and one that came not to your
Aid alone for honour; but incited by heaven,
And justice of the cause, which I was bound
In duty to performe, being a subject,
Though no native, and in that you might
Challenge what was done as duty, not thus
Descend to give me thankes for that which was
Your owne before: For had my starres allotted
Me heire to a Kingdome, this bare
Acknowledgement had beene more than my
Merit could deserve, or state ere recompence.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: A Noble gentleman, and seems the throne
Of vertue: something within me is not
Well; I feele a flame about my heart, which
For the present I must suppresse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your modesty (Honorio) striving
To cloud that voluntary aid you gave us,
With an impulsive duty, does but
(In me) increase your value and lay a
Stronger ground for a more firme affection.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Look this wayes Sir; 'tis these whose true valour,
And brave atchievements, merits this flowing
Language: for what poore service my ability
Coud performe (though 'twas by Heavens all-guiding
Power) directed to a good event,
Yet came it late: but these, when your enemies
Plumes wav'd with triumphant glory on their
Helmets top, these flew like lightning, shot
From the hand of Jove, and blasted those
Rebells in their height of glory: but when
I came, their bravest forces were decay'd,
(Though their number exceeded yours) their
Battalias broken, their Ensignes lost, their
Leaders slaine, and onely a vast confusion
Was their head: there 'twas easie to resist
Where order was not guide.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I should expresse an ingratitude that
Woud for ever blast the name of King,
If not render these that honour their
Valour has deserv'd: tis true, they fought
Bravely, and every stroak, like deaths fatall
Sithe, hew'd downe their enemies before 'hem:
Yet nere the lesse, we had o'most lost the day,
When you like a second Mars brake forth, and
And gave us victory: their helpes most sweet, prevents
The greatest danger.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: There's no contending 'gainst your gracious bounty:
Shield me Divinity, what feele I here!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: VVell Fabianus and Callidus, be neere
In person as affection to us.
And for you Honorio, chuse your place:
You have such freedome as becomes your worth.
Philomusus, though we have hitherto
Beene silent in your praise; we doe confesse
How much we owe to your free noble spirit:
And though traduc't by such whose contagious
Breath will prove their owne bane: tis enough we
Know thy worth, that thou canst as well
Court Bellona in a shade of horrour,
As tread a peacefull measure in a Pallace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This Character my Liege so farre scapes me,
As makes me doubt to whom your intents are Directed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To thee alone Philomusus:
Say Lords, enjoyes not that man a noble Genius,
Who can, and will when warre assaults, lend aid
Unto his Soveraigne, and when faire peace
Triumphs in height of glory, fill all his
Court with pleasure: we have, with no lesse
Admiration, beheld the worthy
Labours of thy Pen, where every Line
Has captivated fancy, then those thy
Brave atchievements in the field.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: VVere I not man, this language were enough
To staine my cheeks with blushes.

sp.speaker: Hon
sp.l: Whats he the King pleases so much to honour?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: One whose praise is no Hyperbole to his worth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well Philomusus, you must spurre on your
Pegasus for some new invention
To Crowne our peacefull triumph: to morrow
We shall expect a Masque.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The time is suddaine, you'll
Not expect it rare.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, no: lead on before

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Tomorrow, 'tis somewhat suddaine,
And startles my invention. Enter Mercutio.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou art hap'ly met:
The King has impos'd somewhat a suddaine
Taske on my weake Muse, to prepare a Masque:
Thou art a pretty Poet, and maist give me
A hint for the device; I have esteemed it
One of the defects in Nature to scorne
Advise from those whose worth cou'd yield it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, I have such obligation
To your merit, that I shou'd count my best
Of labours, crown'd in that act shoud serve you:
Yet withall, so much I prize your honour,
I wou'd not have you (might I presume to
Counsell) draw the same aire with him who is
But thought a Poet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The reason.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O my Lord, experience produces many:
'Twill take off from the glory of your worth,
Shou'd you in your workes expresse a soule
Active as Celestiall fire, a sence
Profound as Oracle; such as wou'd dart
Amazement at the world; yet wou'd the
Canker Envy feed upon your honour,
And charge you with such imputations
As wou'd transport your soule but to imagine,
Much lesse be guilty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How prethee; with what?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have, with an inraged spirit, heard
The Monster-multitude traduce you, and such
Men, whose very hearts wou'd scorne whats not
Heroicke, imputing noble actions as vaine-glorious:
And when their eyes and eares were witnesse
Of your seraphick Contemplations:
Glutted with envy wou'd charge you with
Keeping stipendary Muses: the like
To others, 'cause they inherite more by
Nature than learning does bestow, and whose
Chaste Virgin Muse, wou'd scorne
An adulterate straine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This all (Mercutio?) nay then Ile not doe
Them that courtesie to feare, I shou'd
Esteeme that glory darker than Chaos
Cou'd from their slight breath admit
Privation: no, no, the curse of dulnesse
Pursue 'hem all, I am above their spight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But pray my Lord, where is that exquisite
Sprightly wit, you formerly were wont
To converse withall, I need not name him,
You know him by th' Character.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Very well Mercutio; he has
Throwne away the Laurell, gain'd ith'
Court and City, for a fresher, and one
More free from envy in the field.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: His worth deserves it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No more of this; to the ground of our device;
What thinke you of— Whispers.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: This Court is a brave place to live in: oh if I could come to speake, or be acquainted with the Lord Philomusus, whom the whole Townes long tongue talkes on for the brave wit; and by miracle prove a wit too; I would paint the great Posts at • ny Fathers dore, turne Praetor of the City, and keepe open house for all the wits ith' towne; and some of 'hem poore soules have neede on't: for I have heard they are glad oft-times to feede upon stone in a Cathedrall Church— Those were acute wits by my faith law— I am within smell of some Gallants—and sight of 'hem too — Impudence! O impudence! possesse mee — I will speake to hem—Worshipfull Lords— I have an eternall ambition, to salute you in the lower part—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In the name of innocence—

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: No sir, in my owne name.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis all one, I doe applaud your sweet humility, Honourable Sir.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Y' are mistaken: I was never so much honoured before: indeed I meet with some that worships me sometimes, but you may perhaps prophesie, (as the vulgar terme it) in calling me honourable at first sight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now by Pernassus, he resembles bright Apollo.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Who I Sir, that were fine yfaith—But harke you a word in your eare, I would bee loath to bewray my selfe before every one—but that Apollo was my owne Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Now Phoebus he was.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p:
I have sed it Sir—He sold Sun-dialls at the signe of the
Bay-tree: oh he was as fine a man by report, as ever told what's a Clocke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A youth of Apollo's race! 'fore Iove you must needes be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I hope so: to tell you the troth, my Father was a Citizen, and a Mercer, and having a larger fortune upon his head than the rest of his neighbours, met with good pay-masters, and after his Decease my mother wou'd be sure, if any man tooke up her commodity, he shou'd put in security, which raised her too: but growing old, and finding commings in to be but short, last fall kickt up her heeles, and left me all the wealth she had: Now in good faith Sir, having this estate, I have a great desire to ride in the high way of preferment.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How meane you sir?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: To be made a Courtier, and a wit—I have money enough, and would be loath to have either wit or honour but what be paid for.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He sayes well in that few has.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But I wou'd faine speake with the Lord Philomusus, they say he's able to teach wit, and procure Honour too.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why this is the Lord Philomusus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thou didst ill to discover me.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O I beseech your Lordship to pitty my honourable intentions, and the desire I have to be made a Wit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He might write nil ultra, that perform'd it.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Here's Gold sir: a soveraigne metall for a wit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have no need on't, pray keep it sir: how shal's be rid of him?—I have it; Mercutio dost heare, thou maist want (the Generall disease of Poets) 'twere justice thou didst pursue this humour both for profit and delight: Ile referre him to you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If you thinke fit, I care not to bestow some idle houres on him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Doe so.—Doe you heare Sir, this Gentleman can performe what you desire better, and with more speed than I.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Say you so sir: with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Doe: my affaires call me away. Farewell Mercutio. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good day to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p:
I want onely friends and impudence—Now if I might
be so happy to find both in you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: You shall finde me simply honest.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Of that I make no question: but if you have e're a spare purse of money about you, 'twoud not be cast away, I shall use some in making friends at Court.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Doe they buy friendship here then you shall have money to pay for't—There Sir. Gives him money.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You must have instructions too before you come, how to deport your selfe both in Discourse and manners: my imployments are now somewhat weighty in affaires of State; may I but know your lodging, I shall attend you there at some time more opportune both for your selfe and me.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: With all my heart: I have committed my selfe to the Inns of Chancery, for the better grace; but feeding ith' Commons agrees not with my stomacke; so as I have my dyet in a little Alley hard by at a Cooks house, where you may finde me above the eating houres. You may know the shop by a Calves head commonly in't.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I make no question but to finde you there sir.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Very likely Sir; pray keep your promise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I shall not faile. Enter Flavia. Who's that walkes there so demurely? oh 'tis Flavia, the Court Jennet, one that has try'd all constitutions, complexion, and degrees, from the Lord under the Canopy to th' Page ith' Lobby, was once an easie doing waiting woman, that wou'd fall in love with this Lords begge, and that Revellers backe, till at last su'd, pray'd, and wonne with oathes, wou'd scarce hold breathing, she grew rotten ripe, and fell with every touch (poxe on't, I remember she'd needs trye a Poets straine too) now ith' name of Venery what's she musing on? how to preserve her beauty till the next fall: Ile interrupt her; Flavia how is & wench?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Is what sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is any thing, every thing—What a poxe ail'st? this humour becomes thee scurvily; thou wo't spoyle that little handsomnesse thou hast left. What wouldst thou say wench, if I cou'd helpe thee to a husband, a young husband, a rich husband, one thou mightst Cuckold at his beds feet, and he not a grain the wiser.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You talke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Talke? by this hand I ne're came short of doing with thee yet, though I paid for't—Come, out of pitty I owe thee a good turne, and if I can, will do't.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Alas Sir, He not marry.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Not marry; why what a devill dost thou meane to doe? live to be abhominable ugly, and scorn'd by th' Foote-boyes, goe to Law with Laundresses, for scratching out thy eyes, trust that little stock of money thou hast gathered to set up a house of Garnality ith' Suburbs, with a publicke Notary, he breaks and runnes away to Amsterdam; live too friend lesse, eye-lesse, toothlesse, and thy Nose notable to endure a jest.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I must confesse you alleage strong reasons—But pish, thou dost but jest Marc • t •• .

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why then farewell, and a pox take thee at first, for 'twill have thee it •• end.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I th' once; which end?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why ith' worst 〈◊〉 about thee: prethee let a •• goe.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Stay, this is but Poeticke rage, a Rapture— Tell me who is't?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If thou't be mak'd • e tell thee: 'Tis a Citizens sonne, one borne by inheritance to be a Cuckold; and thy marrying of him will not crosse his Fate.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Doe you thinke to effect it?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Oh you may worke him like Waxe. Tom Fled-wit, and will Plod at his fellow Students in the Innes of Chancery, they'l doe you any courtesie you knows, If they bee not acquainted with him, they shall; like meet 'hem there tomorrow, and propound it.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: If it proceed, and take effect, I am all yours. The Court is risen from supper, I must away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Lord Philomusus expects. Me too: Farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But did my looks betray so strange a Conflict in my heart?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Madam they did; and one but of a dull discerning eye.
Might well perceive those sparkling flames, shot like Comets from your eyes, to speake a stranger fire Had surpriz'd your heart.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Yet strove I to suppresse 'hem with all the Rationall powers of my soule, but it Avail'd not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not to be taxt of flattery, I dare
With confidence affirme, if one that's mortall
And compos'd of earth, (as he that's greatest
Is no more, although compacted of
A purer mold) can but deserve a blisse so
Great as is your love: Honorio is the man.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But prethee lock up ith' privatst concave Of thy breast, the passion I have discover'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ile not name it to my selfe, least the aire Convey it to some others eare.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This shall binde
Me to thy bosome. Enter Honorie and Fabianus.
See Honorio and his friend.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The Princesse in private conference, Lets withdraw.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Prethee come forward enjoy thy wonted freedome.
What Magick spell has charm'd thee into
Dulnesse; come, I gesse the cause: flye not that fire,
For want of which thou thus becom'st a
Frozen Statue.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What starting backe Fabianus? doe you
Make our presence fearefull to your stranger
Friend, one to whom our Country in part does
It Freedome.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Madam not I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Tis well and you con'd possesse me with an
Opinion, that he who has out-fac'd
An Army, shou'd shrinke at a Ladyes
Presence.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Madam, impute it not to feare, but a
Religious awe, that dares not approach
So much Divinity, but with a sacred
Preparation, such as when the holy
Priest, bowes at the Altar of incensed
Deities.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: So late a Souldier, and so soon a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Your softnes Madam, would convert what were Most Barbarous to Civill.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: You wou'd make a fine • amorato.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I shou'd be proud to be what you create mee—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Lady 'thas pleas'd the Princes to entertaine
Discourse with my best friend: will you not
Taxe me of too great presumption, if I
Lay hold on this occasion to present my service.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: To love and honour you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: For your beauty, for those faire eyes that have Transfixt my heart.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, rather hate 'hem, be reveng'd, and wish 'Hem blind as Cupid.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Wish to eclips those heavenly lamps that lend The world their light.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your Courtship is too light and ayrie to
Obtaine beleefe; this language wou'd doe well
To such who love to heare men runne division
On their praise: I can heare you as a Courtier,
But your speeches will as soone finde death in
My forgetfulnesse, as they receiv'd a
Superfluous life from your fluent braine—
Mischiefe of this prevention; I feare
I have too much slighted him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Sir this Noblenesse becomes you, not to
Seeke to surprize a Virgins tender heart,
Apt for any impression, before
You had gain'd her parents liking and
Consent; to which I shall the sooner yield,
Having so sure a symptome of your
Reall worth; if all men bore your mind,
We shou'd not daily view the frequent ruine
Of prepostrous matches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And sir rest confident in me, I nere will Yield my heart, but where you give my hand.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: May thy duty prove to all a faire example.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Sir, I will not urge your hasty answer, though I desire a swift arrivall to my joy.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You say well; things of this nature require
Some respite to resolve; we'll chuse some other
Time to furnish this discourse—There's the
Princesse and your sister; give your attendance,
Urgent imployments calls me away.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Enough, here's Company.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who are these, Honorio and Fabianus?
My heart swells to behold 'hem; 'twere as
Possible a Common-wealth shou'd stand,
When there are two Competitors for th'Crowne,
As I to brooke their glory that eclipses
Mine: Paid not these veines as large
A tribute to that Crimson flood as theirs?
Honour's as blind as fate, and knowes to
Distribute justly: but Ile obscure this passion,
Till a just revenge does meet me.
Worthy Honorio. Noble Fabianus.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Both yours to serve you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: It growes late, lets to our Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Lights there for the Princesse. Ex. omnes, man. Hon. & Fab.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Stay friend a word, what successe?
I perceiv'd the Princesse view'd you
With an attractive eye.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Didst marke it, and retaine thy former Temper; wer't not Planet-strook with those Starre-like eyes?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
There was another, though not in so high A Spheare, by whose influence my heart
Receiv'd a flame.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I did observe your Complement with Clara: Say, dost thou affect her?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Deare, as the expectation of my future Blisse.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O friend thou art happy, there is equality
In fortune betwixt you two: but what alas
Remaines for me that am a stranger, and
A Subject, one she knowes not whence
Deriv'd; his being onely to passe by her with
A silent admiration, till my owne flames
Consume me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come, lets recollect the ornaments of
Man, our reason, and enjoy the treasure
Of our friendship in a timely Councell,
— What fittest course to steere:
Lets to our Chamber, and discourse it there.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: SEE Aurora puts on her Crimson blush,
And with resplendant raies guilds o're the top
Of you aspiring hill: the pearly dew
Hangs on the Rose buds top, and knowing it
Must be anon exhaled, for sorrow shrinkes
It selfe into a teare: the early Larke,
With other winged Choristers of the Morne,
Chanting their Anthems in harmonious aires:
Let those whose sleepes are sound, and quiet as
The dead of night, rise and partake those sweets
This place affords, they are not for me to joy in.
These are the Princesse lodgings,
That her window! Come boy, breath
Out my sorrowes in a mournfull aire.

lg.l: TEll me Jove, should she disdaine,
Whether were it greater paine,
Silent in thy flames to dye,
Or say I love, and she deny.
Flames supprest, doe higher grow,
Shou'd she scorne when she does know
Thy affection; thou shalt prove
A glorious Martyrdome for love.
Better to Loves mercy bow,
She may burne as well as thou:
On then tim'rous heart proceed:
For wounds are death that inward bleed.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What Harmon is that? say who's below?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: The admirer of your vertues Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Who, Honorio?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Was it you that sent those pleasant accents to me?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My duty made me strive to be the first
This morning might salute your care.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I shall find a time for recompence:
'Tis a pleasant walk you tread,
Keep on your path.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your humble Honourer; oh love be now
Propitious, and flatter not my poore
Credulous heart, with a gentle gale of
Comfort, and suffer't to split against
The Rocks of ruine; no, thy heart I know
Is tender as thy youth, and does relent
To know my sufferings.
My friend, I am too narrow to containe
My joy, thou'rt happily arriv'd to beare
A part; I have seene the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Is her highnesse so early stirring?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes Fabianus, and my heart that now
Felt heavier to me than an Atlas load
Shee ha's rarifi'd to ayre.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: See she's descended, with her the Mistris Of my heart.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thus have I seene the dawning day break from The Easterne hills.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Morrow Fabianus.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Your creature Madam: Lady vouchsafe your lip, To Clara
With the Exchange of some few words in private.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You keep still your constant walke Honorio:
'Twas a pleasing ayre you last presented;
Me thought it bare a sound of Love.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Madam, be pleased to give it some other
Stile; for me to sound unto your care that name
Were a presumption farre above his, that
Stole the fire from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You seeme modest, to encrease your value:
Come I know you are in love, who is't
You serve?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Madam, beleeve my tongue was never
Stranger to my heart; at every looke you
Doe create new flames; and like the vestall
Hearth, which once extinguisht, nought
Cou'd replenish, except like Holy fire
Your eyes does wound my heart, and with a smile
You cure againe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Courtiers are so prone, on each slight fancy
Of a Ladyes humour, to beleeve themselves
The onely object of their loves, that we,
Nor know how to give look or smile, but straight
With flattering Oratory they lay traines
To blow up our unspotted honours.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O harbour not a thought so wicked of
My love, lest the entertainment (being
Wrongfully suppos'd) staine the immaculate
Purity of your soule.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir you heare not me accuse you, but in
An affaire so important as is the cause
Of love, she that doubts not, shall nere attaine
To surety.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Pardon, Madam, if with unhallowed breath
I sound what may prove offensive to your eare,
Blame not my forward zeale, you being
The Motive.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: On then.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I love you Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Again I breath my soule—I love you Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Twas boldly utter'd, what prompts you to this Insolence?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh love, I'me blasted.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The Princesse seems mov'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But a storm, 'twill soone be over.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Are you, because a stranger, ignorant
Of our Lawes, which makes it death for any man
To move affection to her, who is
Heire to th'Crowne? if so, you may plead excuse:
Else know you are guilty of a Crime, will pluck
The Lawes severity on your head.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Can Law or torture fright his soule, who is
Every houre extended on the wrack;
No, since you despise me, 'twill adde unto
My future happinesse, when Love shall know
I'me one that dy'd your Martyr, and for my
Body, when entomb'd in earth, a Cypres Tree
Shall spring up from my grave, under whose shade
Such mournfull lovers, as are punish'd
With disdaine, shall come and pay sad tribute
Of their teares, which by that charitable
Aire converts; the falling dew into a frost,
Shall be congeal'd, and raise to my sad
Memory a lasting Monument of
Transparent Christall.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay cleare your brow, I' me none of those that take
Pleasure in tormenting Lovers: 'twere a
Sinne the gods themselves wou'd punish, shou'd my
Disdaine raze so faire a building; retaine
Your manly freedome, although I know it
Sutes not with my birth to give incouragement
To a Subjects love, yet we're bound to
Cherish true worth, though in persons
Of a meaner ranke.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh let me adore the miracle of Nature;
You speak a soule more perfect than an Angels.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Cease these hyperboles, and rest assured,
As time shall increase my opinion of
Your worth, I shall dispose my heart—
But secresie as you expect my love,
Or your own safety—so—farewell: Come Clara,
My Father expects us at the Temple—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I cannot stay sir; but in that ring receive
Your answer.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I accept it as a sentence of despaire or blisse:
—See friend
What happinesse is here contain'd.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Hast prevail'd?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes, and if thy love prospers as mine has done,
We'l both sing hymnes to Cythereas Son. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now Lady, your Fathers goodnesse has left you
To your owne dispose; and I, the admirer
Of your vertues, have free leave to present
My best affection; then save that creature,
Whose life depends on you, whose every
Power ownes not himselfe, but you:
You are that Deity, to whom my heart
Presents its first devotion, and in
A holy flame remains a sacrifice, till
You please accept it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shou'd prove unto my selfe unjust,
In the neglect of one that nobly loves:
Therefore what affection I may bestow,
And yet retaine my freedome, I meane
That freedome, by which I may on just occasion
Withdraw my heart; I were ingratefull
Shou'd I not present.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: May I become the scorne of time, and all
Mens hate pursue me, when I prove so foule
To give occasion you call back your love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cease these hasty protestations, and
I assure my selfe the purenesse of your soule
Is without spot or blemish; and while you
So continue, I shall boast me happy ith'
Glory of such a choise.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O let me flye into your bosome, and
On your lip confirme my happinesse, there
Study some new way of number to multiply
My blisse—the treasuries of grace and nature,
Were quite exhausted to accomplish your
Perfections.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fie, fie, leave for shame.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This superfluous language; I am none
Of those Ladies that are taken with
Poetick Raptures, verses of their haire,
Flattering Acrosticks, and their names
So dis-joynted with an Anagram, 'twould
Puzzle ten Magicians to put 'hem together
Againe: I esteeme not golden language;
'Twas seldome bestow'd on man, but to
Guild a Copper soule within him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Can you be so cruell to deeme my
Language feign'd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor am I:
I grant you love and Poesie are divine,
Commonly infus'd together, yet
Ordinarily 'tis ty'd to rules of flattery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Farre be it from me to speak a language
Shou'd displease your eare.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, more Oratory would but bring
The rest into suspition, whether it
Be reall, let it suffice, I love you,
And if all occurrents sute my expectation,
'T shall not be long 'fore Hymen scale
The Contract

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Heeres the Courts Quotidian,
Shakes all about him.
sp.stage: Enter Princesse, and Clara; Hon. and Fab.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Marania, why had we not your attendance
To th' Temple? I gesse the cause.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas my happinesse, with her Fathers leave
To hold a short discourse: I hope it does
Not offend you Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: By no means: and if it were of love you
Treated, may you prosper as I wish my owne desires.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You're bounteous Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Noble Philomusus, Enter Philomusus.
My Fathers Court is happy in one so
Much deserving

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You too much honour me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I wou'd have you Fabianus and this
Noble Stranger mutually friends,
Your deserts are so much equall.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'me left out then:
There may be a time for a revenge.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lets embrace, and prove the Trium-viri of
True friendship, happy in this union:
More happy in that you have
Pleas'd to joyne us.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Me thinks Honorio and the Princesse are
In deepe discourse—
Shee smiles in his face—
Darts amorous glances—if she shou'd affect
Him now; I'de wish no deeper Precipice
To his ruine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Madam, the Masquers within are ready.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Then lets away. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: My sublime Mercurian I by all the Codexes of the Law, thou art the Primum mobile of Fancy: If this gull continue but his state of innocence, we shall have Dinners, Sack, and wenches in the Seraglios gratis.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Nay, and we can marry him to Flavia, weele drink, dance, and revell with his wife till midnight, and make him carry the Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
D'ee heare then, be advis'd by me, you two shall 〈◊〉 with slight arguments to disswade him from the Cou ••
〈◊〉 worke him more into the opinion of your friendship: the 〈◊〉 present the match, be you sure to give fire, and wee shall 〈…〉 up I warrant you Lads.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Oracle! as I live Oracle: O I cou'd hugge thee for this, my joviall Juvinell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then be you sure, when J name the party, to seeme to extoll her vertue, beauty, riches, and so forth. And sweare you know her all over to a hair— which you may both with a safe Conscience doe.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Nay, for matter of Knowledge, one oath wou'd serve us, and forty more. Enter Pupillus.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: See he comes, 'fore Iove, feeling for money already — Walke off a little —

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Right worthy Sir, may these ten Angells guard you: Oh Celestiall pocket.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Noble and right generous sir, I doe receive 'hem with as much zeale as a Puritan wou'd cheat his father.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: And when, and when shall I be indoctrinated, as they say, in these rules of wit and Courtship?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why when you will.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Master Pupillus?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Whoop sir, are you here? who! and you too? and acquainted with this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: All of a Messe.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: But hark you sir, one word with you: wil you leave the laudible, credible, profitable practice of the Law, to study wit and Courtship?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Yes indeed will I: Doe you thinke I will bee troubled with your Burgage, Sockage, and Feodum simplex; your French and Latine, more barbarous than beggers Canting: and for a Littleton, 'tis more hatefull to me than a Prayer Booke.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Troth Master Fled-wit I know not what to say, but bona fide, he is one non compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: In-law I am of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So am not I, I commend him for't. Wou'd you have him sit wearing out his Buttons, 'gainst his Inke-besquirted Desk, reading of circumcised Latine in Characters, more antique than Aegyptian Hieroglyphicks, transcribing presidents out of old sheep-skins recorded in Anno Sexcentesimo quarto, till his head and Braines be as drye and hollow as his pumice-stone.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: No, no, they shall ne're bring me to it: what though my Father was a Citizen, and a Mercer, yet my mother was a gentlewoman borne, and who knowes but shee might have a friend at Court like other Citizens wives, to bring their husbands custome, and them trading: if so, there may be good reason, why I have this Courtly itch upon me: Besides, I'me not the first whose' Father has measured Ladies commodities by th' yard; and yet becomes a Coach and sixe horses as well as the best o'm.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: So farre concordat cum recordo, (as a man may say) and perhaps his Father being a landed man, some Courtier was Tenant in Taile with his Mother.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Very likely: but faith Master Pupillus, I cou'd wish you wou'd not leave us.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I tell you I wou'd not be troubled with your Conjuring termes of Law, for the profit you get in ten Michaelmas tearms, when your Gownes and Consciences are soyld and dabled alike.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Believe it sir, were you not our friend, we wou'd not brook this Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Nay be not angry.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p:
Not we sir; because we know every man was not borne
with wit enough to be a Lawyer, but for a gallant of these times, the lesse he has the more in fashion. But what will you doe at Court? 'tis not your five hundred a yeare will maintaine your Masques, Playes, Revells, Races, Tennis, Cards, and In, and In with the Ladies, besides your leash of wenches at livery, and when all's brought to a devastation, what then?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Tis but trading with some Merchants wife when her husband's gone to Sea, to trafficke for Unicornes horne, and I shall never want money to bear me standing: 'tis common amongst your broken Cavalleers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He sayes right, there was one Master Had-land, a decayed Gallant, that had spent all his meanes in those wayes you have nam'd, and having nothing left, but the remembrance of his former glory, strook in with one Mistris Sweet-lips a Com-fit makers wife, and she maintaines him now as bravely as any gallant that weares his sword ith' defence of his back-side.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: This was strange.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Phew—talke of want and be a wit—I'me asham'd on you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, doe but view this gentlemans Physiognomie, does not he looke like one that would be fortunate, or crosse the Proverbe? does not this beard grow in forme of a Senators? Perhaps you'l say he has not that accomplisht wit, learning, or other deserving parts. Why tis ten to one he is the sooner preferred; no matter for desert, that rises leisurely and by degrees, honour preferres head-long those that have not too much wit to hinder it: Why I have knowne a gentleman turne away his man, because hee had more wit than himselfe. Then to see what waies there are by marriage: a Lady of my acquaintance cast away foure or five thousand pound upon a paire of Capering Legges, and a Head of Haire.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Why I have a head of haire, and my owne too could caper for a need: Oh that I cou'd thrust my selfe into a Lady of such a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I can assure you sir, there are stranger fortunes fall upon some mens heads.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Pray don't you thinke, I have a head able to bear as large a Fortune as another man?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A brow for the purpose: I can tell you sir, there is a Lady I cou'd name, a handsome Lady, has somewhat more than every one knowes on—
You know her Gentlemen— in some part.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: O shee has an estate of twenty Aldermen, besides Frank-tenement Copy-hold, and Tenure in Taile in aboundance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: She's of so gentle a nature too, and so drawing.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O delicate.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: I protest Sir, if you can but get to bee acquainted with her, you may write your selfe the happiest man alive.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: When may I see her? I long to be at her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Even when you will.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But what shall I doe; I want hard words to Court her.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: How let me see—'tis no matter, Ile tell you, You have read Littleton, and the termes of Law.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I ne're read any thing else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then you shall Court this Lady ith' Lawyers Dialect, tis new; and cannot but be gratefull.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I doe not care for this Littleton, and the termes of Law; but if I come to't once, have at her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: First lets to the Taverne and drinke Sack, To whet our wits.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Content, a match.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come Noble Academians, lusty Wine Shall make's immortall, there's our Magazine. Exeunt omn.

div.head: ACTƲS TERTIƲS.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: MAn, in perfection of his primitive purenesse,
Was by the gods created just and free:
But forfeiting the Charter of those brave
Immunities heavens bounty had conferr'd
Upon him, in just revenge of his too
Wilfull errour, severall passions straight
Sprung up to force him hold a conflict
In his soule; th'effects of which innated
Frailty make me prone, Honorio, there;
I there's the Kingdomes generall Earth-quake:
No honours, titles, favours, but are confer'd
On him, when every act of mine might claime
A Pyramide; and in honour to brook arrivall
Wou'd force antipathy in what were perfect
Union: what wou'd not Justice in such a
Cause permit? 'twou'd make man conscious of,
And act that otherwise might blemish his
Creation to performe: I have perceiv'd some
Signes of love betwixt Honorio and the
Princesse; if I can prove it true, it will
Be no base revenge to tell the King, since
Custome and the Kingdoms Law stiles such
Presumption treason; I am resolv'd, I over.
Heard them in the presence appoynt to walke
Here in the garden: now in yon thicket
Ile stay, to heare what language passes
Betwixt 'hem: if't be of love, as I doe
Presuppose, my just revenge proves duty Exit behind the Arras.
To my King: I heare 'hem comming, I must obscure

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You're a Lady in whom consist all that
Heaven has rais'd to a perfection:
I am too poore to enjoy so great a treasure,
And shall be ever, till I grow immortall:
Which alone rests in your power to make me:
Tis not your birth or fortune that I court,
Heaven's witnesse with me: for had you bin an
Humble shepherdesse, and I a Monarch,
This love had beene, 'cause 'twas decree'd by Fate:
When I first saw you, me thought my soule was
Forc'd to obey a traunce, and as a vision
My amazed sight beheld you, the
Revolution of those Starre-like eyes deserves
A new Astronomy to contemplate.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It sutes my wish, doe doe, bite on, and
Swallow thine owne Confusion.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Honorio, I have heard you, and as
A lover allow of this discourse: but do
Not too soone betray your selfe to misery:
Alas ther's danger in affecting me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Tis not that thing cald danger can affright
My soule, were you round inclos'd with
Rocks of Marble, whose lofty tops shou'd know
No distance 'twixt the skies and them;
I wou'd with winged speed scale those
Aspiring walls, and in despight of all that
Durst detaine you, beare you in my armes
Beyond the reach of danger.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So insolent! there may be wayes to curb you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This does expresse your will, not power, to
Attaine our safety, if you proceed: faith
Therefore leave to love me, 'twill prove
But the ruine of a worthy man, if e're
It come to light—my poore heart is forc't
To plead against it selfe—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Who shou'd reveale it?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He does not think an eccho is so neare.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Ther's none besides our selves that know it, and Fabianus in whom I durst repose my life.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Stay, who's this?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: None but my friend.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Madam, pardon my suddaine rudenesse; 'tis
My love to him, and duty towards you,
That prompts me to it: the King, with
Rest oth' Lords, are making this way, which
Hastned me hither, where I suppos'd you were.
To give you notice to breake off discourse,
And hast away.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Thy true friendship deserves a Noble
Recompence: our next meeting shall be
This evening in the private Garden:

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I shall not faile: lets haste away. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By the faith I owe to Honour, Philomusus,
The Masque was well perform'd upon so short
A warning—where's Honorio, our but
Divided selfe, partner in heart and
Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He's here my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Honorio, Fabianus, Philomusus, three Jems
Make up the poynt verticall in my Laurell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I serve for nothing: then oh my heart.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: You so much honour us, you make our plenty
Poore; rich onely in the amazement of
Your bounty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Liege, not presuming on my owne
Deserts, but your free Justice to revenge
The wrong'd, I'me bold to preferre a sute.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou canst aske but what will prove
Our honour to bestow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, my Liege, I have no Monopoly
On foot, to draw on my head the curse
Of crying misery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'me confident.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then thus my Liege, the late grudge betwixt
The ancient King of Portingall, and your selfe,
Sprung from the disappoyntment of the
Match, betweene your sister (now Dutches
Of Pavia) and him, by reason of her youth
And beauty, not fit for cold embraces:
And having made you his proclaimed
Enemy (though in your goodnesse you have
Never sought to disturbe the quiet of
His peace) yet by this meanes many of your
Painfull loyall Subjects have sustain'd
Great losses on the Seas, by divers ships
Belonging to the King of Portingall;
Amongst which, certaine Merchants, almost
Ruin'd in their estate and fortunes, this
Morning desir'd me to move your Majesty
To grant 'hem Letters of Mart, for taking,
In recompence of their losses, such ships
Of the adverse party, as their labours and
Good successe, may make them owners of.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Motion's just and noble, and for thy love
To th' right of innocence, we here create
Thee Secretary of State, draw what thou thinkst
Is fit, our royall Hand and Signet shall
Confirme it: and because Honorio, and Fabianus
Shall grow in honour, as in friendship with you,
Honorio we make our Lord high Martiall;
Fabianus publicke Treasurer.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And me not spoken of: I laugh to think
How soone their glory will be Eclips'd.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Onely the contemplation of your bounty
Must prove our gratitude.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Enough—Lead on. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Was he so taken, and eager at the report?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: As an Usurer of a Prodigall at one and twenty; All fire; if thy practis'd iniquity will but suffer thee to dissemble modesty, thou art as sure of him as the Devill of a Catchpole.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You a wit, and question a womans dissimulation; there's ne're a head ith' City so hard but knowes it by experience.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Got to then; doe not you seeme too suddainly won, but hold off with an attractive distance: 'twill make his blood runne hot and higher.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Goe teach a common Gamster to cheat, a Puritane to lye, or a Scrivener to keepe his eares, J neede not your learned Maximes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But harke you, harke you, a word by th' way: if after all my paines, care, and counsell, you shou'd, like an old Hospitall, forget your founder; play the Gypsie and turne honest forsooth, or thrifty, it shou'd be the last charitable act J'de doe for the whole Sexe on you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Condemne me never to know man more if J doe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Goe thy wayes, 'tis a strong oath, and J beleeve thee— J have left Pupillus, with his two legall associates, following in a young Practizers pace to th' Hall ju • ling the Country, Clyents Block-heads together, till their braines bee as light as the cause some of hem goes to Law for—Body o'ne wench J heare 'hem comming—On with your vizard of vertue now, and dissemble me like a holy sister of the loving Family.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: See sir, there is the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O admirable blacke beauty.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: And your noble friend pleading for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Madam here is the gentleman J so much Commended; and though J say it before his face, He is one of a noble disposition, birth, and fortune.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: He sayes very true Lady.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Beauteous Madam, pray honour me to kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Though last in Ceremony, J shou'd be proud To be the first might serve you.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Poxe on't, what a block-head was I, I cou'd not say so my selfe—O 'tis a melting Creature.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: So sir, we have made the way for you, enter now.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: I, I, I cou'd enter, and runne through her too: But what to say when I come at her, I know not—
But I will speak to her, and because she shall
Not say I speak without book, this learned
Littleton shall be my prompter— Takes out a booke and holds it in his hand, and looks on it at the breaches.
Bright, bright Moon-shine of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.l: And why not as well Sun-shine?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh I should come too hot upon her.
— Moderata Misericordia, Lady.
Love like a little theefe has committed Burglary
On my heart, rais'd the towne of my Sences.
And forces me with hue and cry to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alas I have compassion on your flames.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh madam, madam, the best part about me's burnt.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: My heart I meane, and since my eares were
Long enough to reach the report of your beauty,
I have still desir'd—Licentiam interloquendi
With your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: J marry sir, this is somewhat.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh, when J am once in I can tickle her yfaith.
You shall heare me rime too,
This Yeare in which love did my heart into his—
Balliwicke bring: Is just by computation
Tricesimo of the King.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.l: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Fla
sp.l: Beleeve it sir, youle put me downe.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Tis my desire Lady.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You speake in so quaint a Dialect, J understand you not.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Hist friend, what does she meane by Dialect?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A delicate way of speaking.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh, oh, J beseech you Madam let me be a remitter in
Your Grace.—J have chose an action to content you
Besides land of all the Tenures in Littleton: as
Burgage, Sockage, Escuage, Vilienage and Capite,

l.hi: Cum multis alijs quae nunc praescribere longum est.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why Mr. Pupillus, I never knew you were a Scholler before.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Faith no great Scholler neither, 'twas all the fruit of ten yeares going to Schoole.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Marry enough to make a Divine in some Countries,
Where degrees of Schoole are vendable.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Why sir, my father was told by a cunning woman, that I should never learne beyond, As in praesenti, and so J never strove to go further.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then the Asse: 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Madam, my heart does make continuall claime to your love, and hopes we shall be joyntenants in affection.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir, you might call my modesty in question,
To yield my heart at first to one I never saw before.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Woud you chuse a man by th'fore part Lady?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You wound my intention, sir.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: And you wound my heart:
There's thrust for thrust.
But if your coynesse shoud make me prove Felon de se, and kil my selfe, you woud be sorry.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I shoud—but pray sir excuse me, at this time
To hold longer discourse with you, some serious
Affaires urges my departure—farwell noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But one kisse first, and all this gold to buy you Taffata for blacke patches.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Ile not refuse, least you might thinke I scorne.— good day to all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your servants Lady—we'le come and share.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Do so. Exit Favia.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Iack, Tom, a word—

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh love! love! that makes a man a Skelleton:
Let her in part feele the pricke, as well as I,
Of thy inflaming Dart.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What thinke you on't?

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.l: Beyond thought!
Most excellent!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How ist Sir? beare up.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: I, I, but oh this Lady, this Lady—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Troth Gentlemen this Lady is not so taken with him as we thought, and expected; what think you if—but I wou'd bee loath to speak except I thought he wou'd do't.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh any thing gentlemen, any thing—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why then what think you if he were inspired?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: How! inspired? that's very fine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But you know the wayes, and Ceremonies, are Very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.l: O infinite!

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: I care not what it cost, let it be done.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then it shall sir; come, as we goe we will
Discourse of it at large, and to morrow
It shall be perform'd.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Shall I be inspir'd? oh fortunate acquaintance. Ex. omn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy life the forfeit if it prove untrue.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I wish my losse of breath might prove it false:
But 'tis a truth as reall, as is the
Justice of the gods severe: and I may
Safely say, I live preserver of my
Countries fame.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O yee gods, why were Kings made the emblemes
Of your power, when like poore slaves, we're
Subject to the change of various and
Inconstant Fortune; have you snatcht up
Goodnesse from the earth, and left nought to
Inhabit in the breasts of men, but vile
Dissimulation, poyson to friendship,
And the staine to honour; in whom
Shall meaner men dare ever to confide,
When Kings themselves rest ignorant
Where to trust.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, that treachery shou'd inhabit there
Where all men thought Vertue had rais'd her
Mansion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: True; I did beleeve Honorio to be
A man that sooner would have yielded up
His heart a prey to Vultures, than to a
Thought disloyall.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Liege, I can informe
You more: Fabianus is their agent,
In this loves affaire: and at that time
When your Majesty miss'd Honorio,
He came and gave him private notice to
Prevent discovery: this I both saw and heard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He false too? Hells furies take
And confound 'hem all. Will not the whole
World, when they shall heare my daughter
Stoops to a base affection, laugh, and scorne
My vile degenerate issue?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This rage seems Kingly in you: cherish it my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They all shall perish if thou prove this true:
But if false, and that of spight thou hast
Rais'd this vile aspersion, expect a death
So horrid, hell shall startle but to heare it nam'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And 'twere my just desert, if J shou'd live the
Staine of innocence: No my gracious
Liege, if on your Royall word you'll promise
Not discover 'twas J that gave you notice,
Cause 'tmay be a Barre betwixt my love
Marania, and me, whose sister J have
Heard affects Fabianus, J shall discover
The time and place when and where they meet,
Then shall your eye and eare be witnesse of my truth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Upon the honour of a King, Jle not disclose
A syllable to wrong thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then my Liege, this present evening
They have appoynted meeting in the garden:
I beleeve they are neare there already:
I shall attend your person to the place;
But then I hope youle graciously excuse
My absence; Ile wait within your call.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come lets away. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Honorio and Fabianus at one doore, Princesse and Clara at the other.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: 'Twas here I did appoynt him come: to which
He promised.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Madam see, he has already made a strict
Performance.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Honorio you're punctuall in your word.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Madam, I esteeme a promise made to you
As a Religious vow taken before the Altar
Of the gods.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Twas no appointment 'twixt us two, but I
Suppos'd you were in person, as in love and duty,
Neer the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You were not certain then.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: No, but as the needle of a Dyall
Toucht by the Adamant, though with trembling
It move to and fro, yet fixes not,
Till it attaine the North: so though I move,
And walke, yet by a sympathy in love,
Can never rest till I arrive your presence.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Pardon Lady my still labouring heart,
That like a Pinnace, toss'd on the curl'd waves
Of Neptunes watry Empire, at such time,
When with his frowne he threatens destruction
To despairing Sea-men, wou'd gladly arrive
Some happy Haven where to rest secure,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: To finish up the summe of all my earthly
Happinesse i'th promise of your love.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Were that the height of your conceived blisse?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes, and no heaven,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I have heard that affection which can know
A fulnesse to its height, is never permanent:
"For loves noone is instant night.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yet a still growing desire to attaine that
Height argues a more firme affection.

div.stage: King and Callidus behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There they are my Liege;
Obscure your person, and grant me your Royall
Licence to depart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have it: away.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Suppose I shou'd give promise of my love,
By your owne argument you then were at
Your height, so must decline: Come I will not
Promise.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I like that well.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Because I'de keep your love still growing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis too true: oh impudence unheard of.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Love's a child, and fondly desires first one
Thing, then another; and thinks no happinesse
Beyond what he craves; so I desire first
A promise of your love, which if you please
To grant, my fondling heart will still aspire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My life and kingdome next: oh villanous Traitor,

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Excuse my modesty if I then bestow
This slight favour first to play withall, a kisse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am no longer able to containe—
Out Traytors.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Alas 'tis we that are betray'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No; but by the gods deliver'd up to my just rage.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We're all undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Though he be the King, whose sacred name
I bow to, he shall not dare to wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Shou'd the gods themselves come wrapt
In terrour, I wou'd thus oppose 'hem both draws.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You were best commit an out-rage,
Where's our guard? Treason.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My gracious Liege, what
Villanous hand is that which is not blasted,
If lift a weapon 'gainst the sacred
Majesty of a King — oh misery! is it you
Attempt this traitorous act?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We spit that name like poyson in their face,
That dare accuse us: no, let him but gage
His royall word, not to execute his rage
On these; we'll lay our lives and weapons
At his feet.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If not, we vow to dye their Champions.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Insolent Rebells.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Ile move the King for you — Sir I beseech You not to discharge your wrath against those Harmlesse Ladies.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Move not for us alone, for heaven sake
Let him sacrifice us all together.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good Sir smooth your brow, they'l not yield,
Except you promise not to wrong the Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Think not treacherous villains, we promise
Not to hurt, 'cause we stand in feare of you:
We cou'd have come with armed men, that soone
Shou'd have chastis'd your bold usurping spirits,
But that I sham'd the aire shou'd know the
Foulnesse of the deed, my blood beares such an
Interest in it—upon mine honour Ile not touch 'hem.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then to shew how much we scorne the name
Of Traitor: here on our bended knees we
Yield our weapons. Delivers their Swords.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What 'twixt the tender Motions of a father,
And their approved valour which we ought
To cherish, even in our enemies, I feele
My plyant heart yield to a calme discourse.
Stand up —
Tell me Honorio, sham'st thou not, that
Goodly wreath of Bayes, thy deserts
Did challenge to adorne thy brow, which seem'd.
More fresh and faire, then were the twining
Limbes of the Pienean Daphne shou'd now
Decay and wither: didst thou, a stranger,
Aide me 'gainst the Rebels of my State,
And plac't in my bosome prove thy selfe
A Traytor?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Great sir, but heare me speak;
If it be treason for a halfe-pin'd wretch,
When he attempteth food: if it be
Treason for that man who spends his life in
A vale of Teares, after some sad disaster,
When he sees a heaven plac't before him
And aspires to be seated there, then you
May stile my love and zeale to vertue
Treason: But if not, then pardon me, if
The whitenesse of my soule does animate
To tell you, 'tis not justice to oppose what
Fate and heaven decrees.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let not your pride so farre transport you, that
You taxe our justice: 'tis not your wither'd
Bayes can protect you from our thunder, if
We please to strike—Though justice cou'd not blame
Him whose thoughts aspire to heaven; yet that
Presumptuous man, shou'd strive to plucke
Iove from his throne, to be enstal'd
A Deity himselfe, deserves in a flame of
Lightning to be cast to Hell, there to amaze
The damned.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Since no arguments can prevaile, take our
Lives, as sacrifice to your wrath.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And I beseech you, as you are my father,
To grant me this preferment, to be sent
Before 'hem: when we are immortall we shall
Enjoy more freely; and because I have
Not yet made promise of my love, J now
Doe vow—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: No; by that dreadfull Styx, by which the gods
Ne're sware, and broke their vow, I love him:
Nor shall my heart ever admit a change.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I vow the like to thee

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then 'twill be mercy if you take our lives.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: And send us to enjoy each other in Elizium.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, you shall not obtaine that favour at
My hands—stand forth and heare your sentence.
For thee, thou staine to Princely blood, I doe
Confine to your lodging, on forfeit of your life—
Callidus she's your charge; let no private
Messages or meetings passe betwixt 'hem,
As you respect our favour: and for you
Honorio and Fabianus, we sentence both
To banishment: and if after two dayes
You be seene within our Confines, we le
Have you mu'd up, and starv'd to death.
Goe, say we are mercifull you scapt
So well.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What remaines for me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your Fathers faithful service to us excuses you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: For Heavens sake sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, we'll heare no more.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Lets but speake before we part.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I say we'l heare no more.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh Callidus!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This is no time to talke, ith' morning
Ile procure a private meeting for you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh thou ty'st us ever thine: farewell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away with 'hem Callidus— you know your
Sentence, and your time. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Come Honorio, let us two goe finde
A way to death; no salve to cure the mind. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: ACTƲS QƲARTƲS.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I Have promised this morning to give
Honorio and Fabianus accesse toth'
Princesse, which favour they esteeme as flowing
From my friend ship: which I but doe the more,
To keepe my selfe still unsuspected by
The Princesse, who being immediate heire
To th' Crowne, might when the King's deceasd
Severely be reveng'd; 'twas about this time
I did appoynt 'hem come.
They are here already: my Noble frinds,
I attended for you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: How fares the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: And my love?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas poore Ladyes almost spent with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Deare friend, admit us to their sight.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: That we may pay their teares with trebble
Interest; which if our eys, (their spring being
Dry) cannot afford, our hearts shall weepe
Blood, to recompence their sorrow.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O friends, you know I hazard both my life
And Fortunes in this act: however, Ile not
Faile in what I promist: doe but with
Patience here expect a while, Ile bring
Them to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Our best friend.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O yee gods, why d'yee mock mans frailty
With a seeming joy; then snatch it from him,
So to prove his ruine; first make beleeve
My selfe fixt in a heaven of blisse, betweene
A true love and a faithfull friend, then to
Be banish'd from my love, and cause my friend
Performes, but that to which the name doth bind,
(Being trust and secresie) to be a partner in
My sad Exile.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Let not a thought of that raise trouble in
Thy breast: I know it is too narrow to containe
The griefe thy heart already is surcharg'd
Withall; and thou wilt wrong the more
Important cause, if shed a teare for me;
When all thou canst bestow will not suffice
To equall that pearly treasure which every
Houre the Princesse love causes her shed
For thee: See the Princesse and my love.

div.stage: Enter Princesse, and Clara, with Callidus.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh my dearest!
Let me flye into thy armes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fabianus! welcome to my bosome,

sp.speaker: Hon
sp.l: Upon this lip I will breath out my soule,
There leave it a surviving Trophy of
My true affection.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Thou shalt not leave thy soule without the
Substance of thy body: stay, in this kisse
Ile returne it thee agen.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Every conjunction of our lips, does
Propagate a soule, which we no sooner part,
But it is straight destroy'd; O let me bathe
Eternally in your bosome, and in a trance
Convey our selves into Elizium: then we'll
Implore the Deities inhabit, there to stay
Our spirits from returning backe to these
Sad prisons of our haplesse bodyes.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Alas my Clara, we must part; the breath
Of Kings is like the sentence of the gods,
Not to be avoyded.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thou shalt not go: I will turne wood-Nymph,
And shroud my dearest under a grove of
Myrtle, free from the eye of vigilant
Suspition; and for thy guard, a thousand
Satyres, with their upright hornes
Shall stand about us, ready to assist thee
There, being free as our owne thoughts, we'll live
And love, and rest securely happy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This thou maist fancy, but we nere attain to.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then Ile accompany my love—
Madam, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Yes; the Grecian Argia cou'd for her husband
Polynices body, being dead, travaile alone
To Thebes to give him buriall, and shall we
Leave our loves living: no, we'll alltogether sure.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Alas your love arrives at impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: True, for all passages are laid to prevent
Your flight: Madam, perswade your heart to let
Him goe; it may prove fortunate for all:
The King in time, and by my perswasions,
May be drawne to call 'hem from Exile: you
May be sure what I can doe shall ne're
Be wanting—To keep 'hem far enough Aside.
For e're returning.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh thou true friend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A very true friend, and you knew all.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Away, he is no friend to you, or me,
To bid me let you goe: Honorio thou shalt
Not; I will enchaine thee in my armes,
And to thy wrists fasten manicles of teares
To hold thee.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Alas, this makes each minute but a sad Departure.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Besides, the King will anon be stirring, and
Then you'le pluck new vengeance on
Your heads; alas I speak out of sincere
Affection I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Peace Screech-Owle, no mans voyce seemes
Other, that speaks with an intent to part us.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Madam, strive to suppresse this passion, and
Let patience, the good mans remedy in
Affliction crowne the end of all your sorrowes.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh misery past humane sufferance.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thinke not so my dearest; 'tis harder
To conceive, than undergoe. Come Fabianus
Let us take our leaves—thus—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Stand off, and come not neare me at this
Distance: Ile strengthen my imagination
With thy forme; then when thou art gone
I may retaine thy perfect Idea in my sight;
Thus—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Alas your passion forces you to an extasie;
These are but fancies urg'd by your height of
Sorrow; collect your scatter'd sences: thus
On your lips I seale my hearts contract.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: With these teares it shall be writ—
So bid me not farewell, nor will I you,
Least so we send a dart to kill each other:
But turne thou silent that way—
My griefes shall lead me this,
And may my love a happy harbour find
These teares the Ocean and my sighes the wind, Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Clara we must part too the Princesse
Has already taught us how: farewell.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let all such lovers, as are crost by Fate,
Learne here to mourne at our unhappy state. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Friends 'twere not manly to let my tears
Expresse my sorrow; no my heart bleeds inward
At this sad departure: farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Hon, & Fab.
sp.l: Farewell our dearest friend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha, ha ha. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Oh my sad heart, whither will the current
Of my griefes transport thee? my soule
Being fled and left my body, like a
Sepulchrall Statue, fixt here bereft of sence,
Onely knowing how to mourne; me thinks
The fabricke of the earth should tremble,
The heavens be clouded in a vaile of sables,
And weep it selfe in shoures upon the earth;
The Sunne goe shroud it selfe beneath the lower
World, never to rise againe; but cause an
Universall darknesse o're the earth, where
Men shall sit mourning our sad departure:
What can be left for two, so much distress'd,
But death, the period of each mans affliction;
That most unkindly flyes those whose griefes
Wou'd entertaine him; and surely strikes there
(Where but nam'd) they startle?—Friend, why
Doe we stand, as if we grew fixt here,
And cou'd not move.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Can he which beares a burthen, wou'd erac • e
The Poles of heaven, to sustaine the weight, move
To, and fro, bearing that load about him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I must acknowledge you a cause of sorrow
Wou'd force the Genius of the world into
A frenzie; yet mine's as great, 'cause 'tis
For me you suffer; but we, that like well-
Fenced Bulwarks, have together stood the
Shock of warre, when loud-mouth'd Canons
Breath'd destruction to an army shou'd
Scorne to fall as combatants in the Campe
Of love: no, lets with courage goe
Bravely on to meet our Fate: hope has
Not quite forsook us; as we passe I will
Relate somewhat may concerne us both—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Noble friends! whither now? no object
But the earth, what Cloud is this spread o're your
Face, that dimmes the wonted lustre of your
Eyes? by all that's Noble let me know, or
Ile repent I ere was nam'd your friend.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Doe not conjure us by so strict a charme,
We shall but make you miserable.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There's not that act, except it decline from
Honour, has power to make me poorer in
A thought.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Then know we two are banished.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Banished! why Ile be banish'd too then.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O no; stay you, and be happy in your Prince his love.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will not stay— say, what's the cause?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If you will with us as I goe I shall relate
The story; but you must in disguise, or
Youl'le be stay'd; and you shall find ere long,
I had little cause to feare being banished:
But since we must from our best retreat,
Let Passive valour be as th' Active, great. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter Pupillus, Mercutio, Plod, and Fled-wit.

sp.speaker: Pup.
