sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, were you inspired, as you say I must bee, before you came to be a Courtier, and a Wit?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: And d'ee thinke 'tis possible for me to be made one too?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I tell you sir, before these gentlemen your friends, and mine, Ile undertake to furnish you with as much wit as shall serve for a Country Justice, or an Aldermans heire.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Why that's enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But then you must be confident of its operation, part freely with any thing that shall be requested of you in the act; not as an Usurer payes Subsidies, grudgingly.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No, no, I scorne it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Had it not beene pitty, one of your estate and Fortune shou'd have knowne no recreation, but going a mile out of town, with a company of Codsheads, to be drunke with Creame and Stewd-Pruines.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O they are delicate with Rose-water and Sugar.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Poxe on't, Bawdy-house fare: No, after your inspiration you may revell with this Lady, discourse with that Lady, and what you will with the third Lady.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh I am almost inspired at the conceit on it: pray let be done, while I am in the aspiring fit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It shall sir— Doe you heare Tom, goe and prepare Flavia for the project, and bring those properties we agreed on.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Say no more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Whither doe you send him?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: To an Antiquaries study; for strange properties to perform the Ceremonies requisite at inspiration: for we must use Invocations, Incantations, Conjurations, Imprecations, and all for the rare effect of Inspiration.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Blesse me, doe you begin to conjure already?

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: No, he tells you but what he must doe.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But harke you; pray d'ee deale with honest, faire conditioned Devills?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O blemish to our sacred Magicke—Devills!

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O no, pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That thought's enough to ruine all the fabricke of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Good sir, Ile never thinke while I live agen.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I tell you sir, we must invoake the Celestiall Deities— We may beginne the Act, none but the bright Minerva can confirme it

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: And will she come at your call.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, yes, if you performe quietly what we desire.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh most obedient Goddesse.

div.stage: Enter Plod with a Boxe, in which are little pieces of paper rold up: A Table set forth.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Are you come? 'tis well: Is Flavia ready?

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: Onely waits her Cue

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Look you sir, you see these papers.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I, whence came they; from the Lottery?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No sir, they are certaine Collections out of learned and witty Authors, for all humours in an accomplished wit. Now sir, you must eate every one of hem one by one.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: How, eate 'hem?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I ease 'hem, and you shall find they will produce effects as various, as the qualities or conditions out of whom they were collected: now therefore off with your Hat and Cloake, kneele downe with a strong beliefe, imagination, and attention — you two stand to keepe him in that equall posture I shall set him; so, now first with a Scholastique Inspiration: somewhat of a hard digestion, as—

div.stage: "Dulcia non meruit qui non gustavit amara.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O 'twill never downe, I shall be choakt with it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My life Sir we'll helpe it downe—here—so—feare not, I warrant you—is it downe?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Almost—so,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How is it sir?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O 'twas so sweete at first, and so abhominable bitter at the last—

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.p: Why there you relish the conceit sir: for the interpretation of it is; Hee deserves not sweete, that has not tasted bitter.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I have tasted a bitter one; now pray let the next be a sweet one.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: According as we see this work: 'thas a present operation—How doe you feele your selfe inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh I cou'd quarrell about the Etymologie of words, fight about Syllables, and Orthography, chop Logique with my Father, Write Tragedies and Comedies by the grosse: and my fingers itch at an Hen-roost.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Thas wrought bravely, the direct symptomes of an University wit: now for the inspiration of a confident Poeticall wit.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Pray pick out the hard words, if there be any.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There's none in this — you shall heare it.
"This from our Author I was bid to say,
"By Iove 'tis good; and if you lik't you may.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Ile tell you how I like it presently.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come sir, downe with it—

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: So, this past with ease—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How doe you find your selfe affected now?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh that I were in a Play-house—I wou'd tell the whole Audience of their pittifull, Hereticall, Criticall humours—Let a man, striving to enrich his labours, make himselfe as poore as a broken Citizen, that dares not so much as shew the tips on's Hornes: yet will these people crye it downe, they know not why: One loves high language, though he understands it not; another whats obscaene, to move the blood, not spleene: a third, whose wit lyes all in his gall, must have a Satyre: a fourth man all ridiculous: and the fift man not knowing what to have, grounds his opinion on the next man ith' formall Ruffe; and so many heads, so many severall humours; and yet the poor Poet must find waies to please 'hem all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: It workes strangely.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But when they shal come to feed on the Offalls of wit, have nothing for their money but a Drumme, a Fooles Coat, and Gunpowder; see Comedies, more ridiculous than a Morrice dance; and for their Tragedies, about at Cudgells were a brave Battalia to 'hem: Oh Phoebus, Phoebus, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Fore Iove, it has wrought most strangely—Tis well here we're none but friends—how doe you sir?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Ah! pretty, pretty, sure I have talked extravagantly, Gentlemen have I not?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I indeed have you; 'tis of a delicate operation: Now sir, you shall have a valiant inspiration to confront your enemy, or rivall in your Mistresses favour—In this paper is the expiring breath of a great warriour, the last words he utter'd.

q.l: "Tis fit the world should weare eternall night.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Why this will kill me sure.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, hold him fast—tis of a strong operation—So, chew it well, feare nothing—Now it is downe: how is't?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Let me goe, let me goe, the world's too narrow to confine me: Ile mount the skies, snatch Ioves three-fold lightning from his hand, dart it at the World, and reduc't againe to its first desolate Chaos, drye up the Sea with fire of my rage, and puffe mens soules away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We must change this humour: Ile now beleeve a strong imagination's witch-craft: force downe another; read it first: What is't? hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.l: "Enter these Armes, and since thou thoughtst it best,
"Not to dreame all my dreame, lets act the rest.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A fit one, a wanton lovers rapture: give it him, thrust it downe: So, he begins to yield; how is't.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O what have you gi'n me now?

sp.speaker: Mer,
sp.p: Onely to inspire you with a wanton art to winne your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Tis wonderfull provocative, believe me: sure it came out of Ovids-Ars-Amandi: oh for the book of Venus and Adonis, to Court my Mistris by: I cou'd dye, I cou'd dye in the Eli-zi-um of her Armes: no sweets to those of Love: O Love, love, thy flames will burne me up to dust and ashes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We must quench your flames— Pinch him hard.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Harder yet.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Oh—
What doe you doe? what doe you? Alas all's downe againe;
I am as cold as a Cucumber.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: So, I beleeve you are sufficiently prepared:
Now we will invoke the goddesse Minerva— kneele,
Downe with your face to the west: harken with
Attention to what she shall say or request, and be sure to performe it —So, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Does she come yet?

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: No, no, he must invoak first.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou sacred goddesse of Joves brave begot, walk round about him.
Descend to earth, and here make fast the knot
We humble Mortalls have begunne to tye,
And we'll adore thy glorious Deity.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O me, O.

div.stage: Soft Musick. Enter Flavia drest like Minerva with a Violl of Water.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Who calls Minerva from the Starry Court?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Oh 'twas he Lady.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We know the full effects of your desire,
It is this noble youth with wit t'inspire:
Then downe his throat this sacred drinke compell,
Tis salt, and water from the Muses well.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Paugh.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Now let him offer gold to our dispose,
And all's confirm'd with this one pluck by th'nose.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O me—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: What gold have you about you—quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Onely twenty peeces in my fob.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Dis-fob 'em quickly, and present 'hem.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Please you Madam, here's forty Angels to wait on your Lady-ship to heaven agen.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We doe accept 'hem—so live ever blest:
I must ascend to my Aetheriall rest. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So, rise up, all's done: now be confident, and you shall prove a Wit—all.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: But harke you gentlemen: pray what does she doe with money?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Releeves poore Poets, that eats Oads, And Madrigalls: Come lets to the next Taverne, and drinke her health.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.l: Come then—Nay now I am inspir'd,
I will doe things shall make me be admir'd.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: There's a touch of his Poeticall inspiration. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King, Princesse, Clara, Marania, Moronzo, and Callidus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is Honorio and Fabianus shipt and gone?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: They are my Liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tis well: methinkes the aire seems purer since
They both departed: sure if they had stay'd
Their trechrous breath wou'd have infected
My whole Kingdome—But thou, degenerate from
All Princely blood, still mournest their absence,
And with effeminate teares wou'dst move
My pitty to call 'hem from Exile: no,
Sooner shalt thou call backe Time, than move
A thought in me shall yield to't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Deare Father move the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ile blast him dumbe that names 'hem.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No hope, you see the King's resolv'd—My Liege
The Lord Philomusus is secretly stolne away
With them in disguise.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Torture to my soule, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I can assure your Majesty 'tis so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh where's that Subject that a King dares love?
Philomusus gone—

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Oh my Honorio.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Leave this sullen humour Dulcimenta,
Or by just heavens I will disclaime you mine;
Though youth and errour lead you to a fault,
(Which I may study to forget, upon conformance
Of your will with mine) will you pursue
The cause, and peevishly consume your selfe
In teares, for him whom the gods themselves
Doe hate, for spotted treason gainst your Fathers
Person; it cou'd be no lesse when he attempted
To match the Kingdomes heire—goe to, raise
Not my fury to that height, which if it fall,
Shall crush you to your ruine.

sp.speaker: Prin
sp.l: Sir, thinke not a disobedient passion guides
My will to love or hate, contrary to your
Mind; but since 'tis so, heaven has it selfe decree'd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Away, taxe not the heavens with what's unjust
They ne're decreed the blood of Kings should
Mixe with Traytors.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sir, they were no Traytors.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis well, defend 'hem still.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: No, their innocence will do't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Very good; I perceive from whence this
Springs; your company with Clara feeds this
Rebellious spirit, does it? I have an easie cure for that:
M •• onzo keepe your daughters to you; there's
Neither of 'hem we'le admit to attend her, since
Favour is abus'd, we can restrain it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Their lives and mine are prostrate to your will.
Come daughters—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Stay: Sir has tyrannie usurpt the seat of
Mercy in your royall breast: if so, let death
Part us, and so end our woe.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I doe beseech you, as you are my Father,
By your wonted love to me, or whatsoe're
You hold more deare, bereave me not both of
My love and friend together; this cruelty
Exceeds the former; lover is a name may
Be in time dispenc'd with; but a friend, oh,
A true friend, heaven knowes not a happinesse
Beyond it: deare sit, by my dead mothers ashes,
Which were you neare, wou'd (in imitation of
Those amorous twines which did inchaine
Your hearts) flye up, and hang about you,
Gently to chide this most unnaturall act:
Which, because distance of place denyes it,
Send but to know, and you shall heare
The Marble Tombe weeps at this disaster.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The remembrance of her dead mother
Wou'd stir my pitty, shou'd I not resist it:
I must suddenly Callidus, convey our
Daughter to her lodging; we'll appoynt
Some other Ladies to attend her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No more, we are resolv'd: Moronzo
Performe what we command.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I shall my Liege: come daughters.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lead on. Ex. severally.

div.head: ACTƲS QƲINTƲS.
div.stage: Enter Mercutio, Pupillus, Fled-wit, Plod, and Flavia.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: HOw? and how stands the businesse?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Nay, you know best.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Perceive you not an alteration, or transmutation in my outward person?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Me thinks your words fall off your tongue with a more becomming grace.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Thinke so: be wise and catch 'hem as they fall: they may inspire you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You are strangely metamorphos'd since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Mutor pro temporum ratione, as the learned say.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's the fruit of his Scholastique inspiration.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: O Lady, if your heart bestone, I wou'd 'twere broke.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: I have heard men wish their Mistris heart wounded, never broke.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Pshew, my love is not like other mens, that will whine and crye, looke pale, and weare night caps: no, my love is a bouncing love, and makes no more of cracking a Ladyes heart, than a Squirrell of a Nut.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A notable crack.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: For harke you a word in your care (I wou'd not have these Gentlemen know it) I am inspired.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Now by Diana is it true?

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: I have sed it, be wise and have me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O you men have such strange wayes to play upon poore women.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Nay, there's but one way I'de play upon you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: And will dissemble most egregiously.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Who I dissemble? why these Gentlemen will sweare all my acts are simple.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Nay Lady, I know he has not a thought but what is meerly innocent.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: If you'll but marry me, there is not that desire, or inclination, which you shall have; but I will strive with my best part to satisfie: what wou'd you more?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I must confesse you promise faire.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: And will performe as well.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Alas my Virgin feares bid me I shou'd not yield.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A poxe of your Virginity.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I know not what to doe.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Come, I know what to doe, and you'le say but I once.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Madam, it can be no blemish to your modest Vertue, to yield your love at first to one, whose Worth and fortunes equall yours.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Why then I wholly yield me yours.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: That's well said, this kisse in earnest; come, we'll not stand long upon the businesse, but bee marryed presently: I must provide Ribbond for all the Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You may save that cost; their hats are so stuff'd with Ribbons already, they'll finde no roome to weare 'hem.

sp.speaker: Pup.
sp.p: Poxe 'tis a French fashion: I warrant there are some wou'd change their very faces with a French man to be a la mode, but come, you two shal lead the Bride, and you shall give her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You shall command us.

sp.speaker: Pup,
sp.p: Soe, soe. Hymen! O Hymen snuffe thy torch and see A paire of Lovers, leads their way to me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Whither is compassion fled, that should
Inhabit in the breasts of men, and make
Distinction 'twixt their knowing soules, and
Sencelesse cruelty of savage beasts, guided
By their wills to ruine, not reason, how, or whom;
When he that beares the title of a King,
And Father, can nor find mercy in the one,
Nor love ith' other: oh you sad lovers that are
Crost by Fortune, and your Parents hate, come
Pay your floods of teares, as tribute
To my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Madam be pleas'd to retire and repose your
Selfe; sorrow and want of rest must needs impaire
Your health: thinke not because she, whom
You please to honour with the name of friend,
Is taken from you, that none is left true
And faithfull to attend you; yes, I am one,
Though young in service to you, would (if made
Happy ith' triall) embrace a danger, to
Assure your quiet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Can this be reall?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Yes, as your griefes are true.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is there one left faithfull to attend me
Now my Clara's gone? If so, prethee
Conduct me to some gloomy vale,
Wrapt with unpleasant shades of Yew
And Cypres, sprung up from lovers graves:
On which the croaking Raven, with other Birds
Of night may sit and hollow sad accents;
Such as may fitly simpathize with mourning:
A murmuring brooke of wronged Virgins teares,
That may glide softly by, and receive mine,
To augment their streames: a bed of Mosse,
Gather'd from Vaults and Charnells, where
The dead inhabit, to repose us on, there
Thou and I will sit and feed on sorrow,
That shall feede on us, and when we
Both are dead, some distracted Muse fled
To those groves, shall in an uncouth
Tone sing our sad Requiems.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I was plac'd by your father, in hope I might
Have remov'd this passion; but your discourse
Makes me an object rather to incite you mourne,
Then otherwise: let me intreate your highnesse sit
And repose your selfe: Ile trye my voyce to charme
Your eyes and heart with pleasing slumbers.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Most willingly, some rest in sorrow will do
Well—Begin.

lg.l: CHarme, oh charme, thou god of sleep,
Her faire eyes, that waking mourne;
Frightfull visions from her keep,
Such as are by sorrowes borne:
But let all the sweets that may
Wait on rest, her thoughts obey.
Flye: oh flye, thou god of love,
To that breast thy dart did wound,
Draw thy shaft, the smart remove,
Let her wonted joyes be found:
Raise up pleasure to a flood,
Never ebbing; new joyes bud.

sp.l: So my Charmes have tooke, poore Lady
She has not enjoy'd so much quiet rest,
Since Honorio and Fabianus left
The Court. Enter Callidus.
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis I Lady: How fares the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Speak lower, she's asleep.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good heaven be prais'd, she may in time
Forget her griefes.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Not till the King forget his cruelty:
I dare not say the name of King gives
It a more modest title.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I must confesse, 'tis little lesse—but Subjects
Must not see, much lesse say, what mis-becomes
Their Prince; 'tis enough we performe what they
Command, not question why.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh my Clara: oh my Honorio.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Shee wakes.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Who's that Callidus?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes Madam, the King commanded me to give
Your Highnesse notice, last night Embassadours
Came from Portingall to Naples, and the King
Hath already given them both audience and
Their answer, and they are making a speedy
Returne backe from whence they came, the
Reason of their comming or businesse I understand
Not: but 'tis his Majesties pleasure you instantly
Repaire to him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: More corrasive: well, my duty binds me
To awaite his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I shall attend your highnesse.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: My sad soule presages some new affliction.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Take comfort gracious Madam.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: There is no rest I ever hope to have,
Till heaven decrees I rest within my grave. Ex. omn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords, what think you of the match
Betwixt the Prince of Portingall, and our daughter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Without question my Liege, 'twill prove
Fortunate for both, if the Princesse
Can be drawne to affect him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I make no question but to winne her to't:
Are the Ambassadours return'd for Portingall?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They are my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis well, we expect his arrivall suddainly:
Moronzo, let it be your charge to see all things
Correspond so great an entertainment—
Where's Callidus? we sent him to attend
Our daughter hither.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They are here my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What mourning!
This habit ill becomes you, knowing it contradicts
Our will.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, it best sutes my thoughts,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It best sutes the blacknesse of your disobedience.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sir, name but that thing, rests in my power to
Divert your anger, my duty shall lend me wings,
On which Ile flye to act.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your speeches are but aire, there's no performance:
You insult too much upon the softnesse of my temper:
But heare me now with that attention thou
Wou'dst an Oracle, pronouncing of thy fate,
What my will decrees.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: If death, I shall embrace it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then briefly thus, Portingalls great King
Our late enemy, Fame reporting what
Thou least deserv'st, vertue and obedience,
Has by Embassadours, 'twixt you, our Kingdomes
Heire, and his sonne, treated of a match;
Whereof (because 'twill be a meanes to unite
Our Kingdomes, which have beene long at variance)
We have accepted, and return'd this answer,
That if he please in person to come for you,
He shou'd enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: O my Prophetique soule!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This will make sure for ever against Honorio
And Fabianus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thinke but the danger will ensue, if you refuse:
First, to mock the expectation of a King
Can bring no lesse than warre upon our
Now peacefull Kingdome: next, the shame
Of forraigne nations: and lastly, my curse
Pursues thee to thy grave, if thou refuse:
Thinke on't, theres no delay, the Prince will with
Speed be here, and claime our promise:
Therefore let your face beare smiles, to expresse
His welcome; if your obedience will prompt you
To doe this, you shall, besides the height of
Happinesse in so blest an union, enjoy againe
The company of Clara, the freedome of
A Queene, and all the pleasures earth can bestow.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And all wil prove but torment without Honorio.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She's ith' same note still.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Dulcimenta, you know our will,
Which if not perform'd, Exit King, cum alijs, man. Prin. and Lady.
By all my hopes, I sweare thy Fates decree'd,
My curse pursues thy soule, thy heart shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Every houre creates but a new torment.
Was ever cruelty like this? is't not enough
To banish him I love, but force my affection
On another? rob me of my blisse, and not
Afford me quietly to mourne: in what
A strange Dilemma is my soule perplext?
Death I meet, whether I refuse or yield:
Which of those two instruct me Love;
If J yield, 'twill be a death Mortality,
Knowes not to sustaine; because to live
With one J cannot love: if deny, 'twill
Be an easier death; but then a curse
Will make my paines eternall: say J
Avoyd the curse, and match this forraine Prince,
The curse of Lovers will pursue me
For the breach of faith:
On then, J am resolv'd, Jle rather dye,
Curs'd for my faith, than for inconstancy. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mercutio, Plod, Fled-wit, and Flavia.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he's as foxt within, as a Constable by mid-night:
Thou hast him sure wench now.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: As fast as the Parsons tongue, and Their consents could bind 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Now thou must remember thy Benefactors in the dayes of thy prosperity.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.p: We shall share I hope in your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Even all alike.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: De'e heare gentlemen, you have draind him pretty well already, bin paid for your labours—Beleeve it, you have all you are like to have of him, or me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, thou dost but jest wench.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: You shall finde I speak in very good earnest: If a supper, and a sack posset can content you, you shal be welcome; for any other matter, you see the interest you are like to have of him or me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Canst thou so wickedly forget thy friends?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: No sir, 'twill prove vertue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Canst thou name that thing cal'd vertue?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes sir, and will learne to practice it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The devill thou canst.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Patience sir, in this case, will prove your best
Remedy: You have my resolution Gentlemen,
And so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Poxe goe wi' you, and all the dissembling generation of you—Now Gentlemen where's our dinners, sack, and wenches; our mid-night revells, and what not?

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.p: Guld by a woman: now the curse of an insatiate desire pursue 'hem all.

sp.speaker: Plod.
sp.l: Lets home, and study mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No faith, lets learne to live better,
And goe sober to bed.

sp.speaker: Fled.
sp.l: That we shall never doe. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King, Moronzo, Callidus, with Attendants, at one side of the Stage, a Lord disguised, as Prince of Portingall, Honorio, Fabianus, Philomusus disguised as Attendants at the other.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cease Musicke.
Welcome great Prince to Naples, and so
Are all about you. A shout.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The people second it with acclamations of their joy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The bounty of your Kingly love transcends our Expectation or desert.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Our power attaines not the performance of our will.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: If you strive to out-vye friendly expressions,
My stocke of language will not extend to see't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Great sir, how fares your Princely daughter,
Whom Fame reports fitter to consort with
Angels, than to match Mortality.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You'll find fame has beene too lavish sir—
Call forth our daughter.

div.stage: Enter Princesse, Clara, Marania, and Lady.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thus Aurora blushing proclaimes the day.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Why sigh you Lady?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: To think a Prince shou'd come to sue
For what I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: How's this? is her affection plac't else where?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Were it so, no doubt you have Oratory sufficient
To divert it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I did beleeve you had before we came prepar'd
Her heart to give us entertainment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I did; and thought your presence would have
Remov'd all obstacles to hinder your enjoying—
Away thou scorne of time.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: This strange and unexpected—Your patience Sir,
Ile trye my fate—Lady it should seeme you
Have already dispos'd your love: Ile not dispute the
Worth of him you have pleas'd to make so happy:
But behold I bring a heart, fraught with as true
Affection, as ever man could boast; a title too
That may deserve you: refuse me not, 'twas fame
First tooke my eare, your beauty now my heart.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Wou'd I had lesse of both, since both prove so unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis you make 'hem so; demolish not with sorrow
Such a beauty, as were enough for all your sexe▪
And make 'hem proud to know 'twas part of yours.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Retaine this language for those whose height
Of love can meete your flame; tis vainly
Bestow'd on me; my heart's already fixt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let me rip out that heart, the Cabinet
Of rebellious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Good sir, give not so much scope to fury.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: To take all cause of further sute away,
Receive my story and resolves in one:
Then let him sacrifice my heart to love,
And I shall live triumphant after death,
Dying that causes Martyr, however,
Great Prince, deeme not a Ladyes worth impair'd,
When I declare I lov'd beneath my birth.
My father, at his returne from warre,
And bright Conquest shining on his sword,
Brought with him one, whom he himselfe
Esteem'd the mirrour of valour, and heroicke acts;
His name Honorio, whose descent unnam'd,
None knew from whence, except the child of Fame:
That Noble Stranger's merit wonne my heart,
And so we two grew of one faith, one mind,
Till adverse fortune envying our blisse,
We were betray'd; he banish'd from me,
And I alone left to deplore my fate:
Now let all know, by heaven's I'me fixt, nere
To enjoy another.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Excellent Lady! I take you at your word; discovers.
And thus receive your onely true Honorio.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ha! where?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: So, I must resigne.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Here in me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How's this!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: For firmer proofe, see Fabianus here. Fab. discovers,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Amazement seazes me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thus I bring home a true love to my Clara,
A loyall Subject to my Prince.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My dearest love.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh are these joyes essentiall?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our Guard there, off with their heads: doe you mocke
Our fury with impostures?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: They deserve your utmost rage.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: How—Stay your fury till you have a cause.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: May I beleeve this happinesse?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Tis a truth as reall as we thus embrace.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh Fabianus live I to enjoy thy love!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Thou dost; on thy lip I doe confirme my blisse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are not you that same Honorio, whom
I exild with Fabianus there?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And dare you set foote upon our Confines
After such a Censure?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Yes, but not as Honorio onely; but as Prince
Of Portingall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How, you Prince of Portingall?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: As sure as you are King of Naples.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: By Circumstance Ile mak't appeare:
The fame of this blest Lady, spred through
My Fathers Court, wing'd my desires to view
So much perfection; which made me take
Occasion of your present warre, to insinuate
My selfe in favour of you and of the Court,
But durst not presume discovery, by reason of
The unhappy difference 'twixt our Kingdomes,
(The cause whereof has beene related) then at the height
Of happinesse, some envious fate possess'd you
With the knowledge of our loves, so banish us:
In whose supposed Exile, this noble Lord became a Philomusus discovers.
Willing partner, and I bare him with me
To my Fathers Court; which that 'tis truth
He's able to enforme you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, upon the safety of my life he speaks all truth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost thou confirme it Philomusus?
Then 'twere sinne to beare the least suspition;
Be neare us, thou deserv'st more honour than
We can bestow—Pardon great Prince the
Severity of our anger 'gainst your person
When you were unknowne: but in requitall,
Here receive our daughter, with free consent,
And prayers to prosper both.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Fabianus and Clara, I thus joyne your hands.
Heavens send you joy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh Callidus, thou wert the instigator of my Anger.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So, all will out I see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Who Callidus?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: What our friend?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Plainly I now perceive he cloathed his spight
Under pretence of duty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Pardon I crave, J doe confesse J gave too great
A scope to envy and ambition, that a stranger
Should so much deserve your royall — And then
A hope to obtaine those honours should be took
From him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gracious Soveraigne, I beg his punishment
May be refer'd to me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be it so.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then I expect mercy; for you love —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did, before you prov'd false to the name
Of friend; but now resolve never to wed you:
And 'cause Ile not torment you to see another
Possesse my love, and for ever to keep my selfe
From solicitation, call forth a Priest of Vesta.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What will my dearest doe? Enter Priest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus vow my selfe a Recluse.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am happy in so blest a Child.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: The mirrour of her Sexe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then Callidus away, and learne to amend hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Marania thou art cruell—Your Majesty hath
Shewne me mercy; I obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now set forward toward Hymens Temple,
To confirme these Nuptialls; and
Let all stile it, that shall heare this story,
The Noble Stranger, or eclipsed glory. Exeunt.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: OƲr Author knowing Fortitude's approv'd,
When dangers threaten, if it stand unmov'd:
He, without feare, freely presents his cause
To you, for condemnation, or applause.
Reserve severer doomes, for such as dare
Boast their owne worth, he cannot feare or eare:
Mistake him not, he vowes he is as cleare
From bold presumption, as he is from feare.
And if his Stranger has gain'd liking we' yee.
Faith then shake hands, and bid him welcome te' yee.
